{{marriage|[[Therese Dahn]]|1873|1912}} }} '''Felix Dahn''' (9 February 1834 – 3 January 1912) was a German law professor, [[German nationalism|German nationalist]] author, poet and historian. ==Biography== Ludwig Julius Sophus Felix Dahn was born in [[Hamburg]] as the oldest son of Friedrich (1811–1889) and Constanze Dahn who were notable actors at the city's theatre. The family had both German and French roots. Dahn began his studies in law and philosophy in [[University of Munich|Munich]] (he had moved there with his parents in 1834), and graduated as [[Doctor of Laws]] in [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Berlin]]. After his [[habilitation treatise]], Dahn became a lecturer of German Law in Munich in 1857. In 1863 he became [[senior lecturer]]/[[associate professor]] in [[University of Würzburg|Würzburg]], received a professorship in [[University of Königsberg|Königsberg]] (in 1872). Dahn was married to the artist Sophie Fries (1835–1898), with whom he had a son. He tutored baroness Therese von Droste-Hülshoff, a relative of the poet [[Annette von Droste-Hülshoff]], in poetry from 1867 and entered an illicit love affair with her, which he gave a literary treatment in his ''Sind Götter?'' (1874). He divorced his wife and married Therese, against opposition from both families, in 1873. Dahn relocated to [[University of Breslau]] in 1888, again as a full professor, and was elected [[Rector (academia)|rector]] of the university in 1895. As rector, he enforced a ban on Polish student associations.[[Norman Davies]], ''Microcosm'' (2003), p. 305 He was an honorary member of [[German Student Corps]]{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} and an active member of the nationalist ''[[Alldeutscher Verband]]''. Dahn received honorary doctorates in Medicine and in Philosophy. Dahn died in [[Breslau]], a month before his 78th birthday. ==Works== Dahn's writings were influential in the conception of the European [[Migration Period]] (''Völkerwanderung'' ) in German historiography of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. His multi-volume ''Prehistory of the Germanic and Roman Peoples'', a chronology of the Migration Period that first appeared in print in 1883, was so definitive that abbreviated versions were reprinted until the late 1970s. From the 1860s, Dahn regularly wrote for ''[[Die Gartenlaube]]''. His nationalist historical novels were widely received, and according to Houdsen (1997) were influential in the formation of the ''[[völkisch]]'' ideology that formed the "Germany's pre-Hitlerian intellectual background for National Socialism".{{Cite book |quote=The philosophies of Fichte, Hegel, or Nietzsche did not contribute as much to Germany's pre-Hitlerian intellectual background for National Socialism as commemorations of the victory at Sedan (in the Franco-Prussian War), Bismarckian blood and iron quotations, the historical novels of Felix Dahn |title=Resistance and Conformity in the Third Reich |first=Martyn |last=Housden |year=1997 |publisher=Routledge |page=3 |isbn= }} His 1876 ''[[A Struggle for Rome|Ein Kampf um Rom]]'' according to Kipper (2002) contributed to the [[ethnic essentialism]] and opposition to [[Miscegenation|ethnic miscegenation]] of the "völkisch avant-garde".[http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.cgi?path=266781088192848 Rainer Kipper. Der German mythos in Deutschen Kaiserreich: Formen und Funktionen historischer Selbstthematisierung. Göttingen: Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, 2002. 394 pp.] {{ISBN|978-3-525-35570-1}}., review at ''Humanities and Social sciences - Online - Net'' Dahn published numerous poems, many with a nationalist bent. His ''Mette von Marienburg'' portrays bands of "[[Masuria|Masures]] and Poles" hiding in the "[[Podolian Voivodeship|Podolian]] forest".''Gesammelte Werke. Band 5: Gedichte und Balladen'', Leipzig 1912. The comparison to packs of wolves is mentioned as stressing the "implacability of the Poles" alongside the writings of [[Arthur Jonetz]] and "many other German nationalists" by {{Cite book |title=German Nationalism and Religious Conflict: Culture, Ideology, Politics, 1870–1914 |first=Helmut Walser |last=Smith |year=2014 |page=173 }} Besides his historical and literary production, Dahn also published a large amount of specialist legal literature, on topics such as [[trade law]] and [[international law]]. ==Bibliography== *1861 - 1911 ''Die Könige der Germanen'' (''Germanic Kings'', 11 parts) *1865 ''Prokopius von Cäsarea. '''Gustaaf Johannes Petrus Renier''' (25 September 1892, [[Vlissingen|Flushing]] – 1 September 1962, [[Twickenham]]) was professor of Dutch History at [[University College London]].
==Life== Renier was the child of Johanna Maria Elisabeth Renier and the [[maritime pilot]] Peter Paul Renier,<ref>H. van der Hoeven, [http://www.historici.nl/Onderzoek/Projecten/BWN/lemmata/bwn1/renier Renier, Gustaaf Johannes Petrus (1892-1962)] at historic.nl (in Dutch)</ref> both natives of Flushing.<ref>[http://www.genealogieonline.nl/en/stamboom-afens/I4717.php Genealogy page]. Both biographies erroneously describe Renier's mother as [[Walloons|Walloon]]. Both his grandfathers were from [[Ostend]], West Flanders, his grandmothers were locals from Flushing and [[Middelburg]].</ref> He was sent to school in [[Antwerp]] and [[Leuven]], and studied History at the [[University of Ghent]], beginning a doctorate under [[Henri Pirenne]]. At the outbreak of the First World War he fled to England, and remained there working as a journalist, biographer and translator, before completing a doctorate under [[Pieter Geyl]]. In 1936 he succeeded Geyl as Reader in Dutch History at [[University College London]], retiring in 1957.
In contrast to his former advisor, Geyl, he took the view that Dutch and Belgian nationhood were highly distinct.
==Works== *''Great Britain and the Establishment of the Kingdom of the Netherlands'' (1930) *''The English: Are They Human?'' (1931) *''The Ill-fated Princess: The Life of Charlotte, Daughter of the Prince Regent (1932) *''William of Orange'' (1932) *''Oscar Wilde'' (1933) *''He Came to England'' (1933) *''Robespierre'' (1936) *''History, its Purpose and Method'' (1950).

{{Infobox person | name = George Darling Watt | image = George D. Watt.JPG | birth_date = {{Birth date|1812|05|12}} | birth_place = [[Manchester]], England | death_date = {{Death date and age|1881|10|24|1812|05|12}} | death_place = [[Kaysville, Utah|Kaysville]], [[Utah Territory]] | death_cause = | resting_place = Kaysville City Cemetery | resting_place_coordinates = {{Coord|41.046462|-111.926819|display=inline}} | monuments = | notable_works = Primary editor of the ''[[Journal of Discourses]]'' and the primary inventor of the [[Deseret Alphabet]]. | spouse = Molly Gregson, Jane Brown,<ref name = "Watt">{{Citation | last = Watt | first = Ronald G. | title = Sailing 'The Old Ship Zion': The Life of George D. Watt | journal = [[BYU Studies]] |date=Fall 1977 | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 56–57 | url = http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/byustudies,573}}</ref> Alice Whittaker,<ref name = "Watt"/> Elizabeth Golightly,<ref name = "Watt"/> Sarah Ann Harter,<ref name = "Watt"/> and Martha Bench<ref name = "Watt"/> | children = At least 11.<ref>[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/125223 George Darling Watt] Find a Grave</ref> | parents = James Watt and Ann Wood }} '''George Darling Watt''' (12 May 1812 – 24 October 1881)<ref name=birth>Ronald G. Watt wrote in 1977 that the birth was in December 1815 {{Harv|Watt|1977|p=49}}, though in a much later publication he claimed it was 12 May 1812 {{Harv|Watt|2000}}. Additionally Watt's grave has [http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=pv&GRid=125223&PIpi=30109358 two tombstones], which list both [http://image1.findagrave.com/photos/2010/178/125223_127778476231.jpg January 16 1815] and [http://image1.findagrave.com/photos/2010/178/125223_127778469813.jpg May 18, 1812] as birth dates.</ref> was the first convert to [[Mormonism]] baptized in the [[British Isles]]. As a member of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church), Watt was a secretary to [[Brigham Young]], the primary editor of the ''[[Journal of Discourses]]'' and the primary inventor of the [[Deseret Alphabet]].
Watt was born in [[Manchester]], England. While living in [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]] as a young man, Watt was a member of the Reverend James Fielding's congregation. Fielding's brother [[Joseph Fielding|Joseph]] had joined the [[Church of Christ (Latter-day Saints)|Latter-day Saint church]] in [[Upper Canada]] and had written to James about the new church. In 1837, [[Missionary (LDS Church)|Latter-day Saint missionaries]] [[Heber C. Kimball]], [[Orson Hyde]], [[Willard Richards]], and Joseph Fielding traveled to Preston and were given permission by James Fielding to preach in his chapel.
Watt was baptized a [[Latter-day Saint]] on July 30, 1837 by [[Heber C. Kimball]] in the [[River Ribble]]. Watt won the right to be the first official British [[Latter-day Saint]] convert by winning a footrace against eight others from Fielding's congregation that desired to join the [[Mormons]]. In 1840 and 1841 Watt served as a Mormon missionary in [[Scotland]]. In 1842, Watt left England to join the gathering of the Latter-day Saints in [[Nauvoo, Illinois]].
In 1846, [[Brigham Young]] sent Watt and his wife back to England as church missionaries. Watt used his skill at [[Pitman shorthand]] in serving as a clerk to [[mission president]] [[George Q. Cannon]]. In late 1850, the Watts returned to America and joined the new gathering of Latter-day Saints in the [[Salt Lake Valley]] in [[Utah Territory]].
In Utah, Watt worked as a reporter for the ''[[Deseret News]]'' and as a private clerk for Brigham Young. Using his skill as a stenographer, Watt began recording the sermons given by Young and other LDS Church leaders. Beginning in 1853, Watt published these sermons in a periodical known as the ''[[Journal of Discourses]]''. Watt remained the primary editor of the ''Journal'' until 1868.
In 1852, Watt was appointed by Young to a committee that was charged with creating a new phonetic alphabet that would assist non-English speaking Latter-day Saint immigrants learn English. The result was the [[Deseret Alphabet]]. Although the alphabet was largely a failure, Watt remained a strong promoter of the language system.
In 1869, Watt was disfellowshipped from the LDS Church for following the teachings of dissident [[William S. Godbe]]. Watt was identified as one of the leaders of the "[[Godbeites]]" and was disciplined by the [[Quorum of the Twelve Apostles (LDS Church)|Quorum of the Twelve Apostles]]. Although Watt was initially repentant and desired to return to full fellowship in the LDS Church, by 1874 he was a devoted [[Godbeite]] and was excommunicated from the LDS Church on May 3, 1874.
Later, Watt tried to return to the LDS Church. Four times he attempted to rejoin the church but was denied because his beliefs differed from those of the LDS Church.<ref>{{Citation | last = Watt | first = Ronald G. | title = Sailing 'The Old Ship Zion': The Life of George D. Watt | journal = [[BYU Studies]] |date=Fall 1977 | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 17 | url = http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/u?/byustudies,573}}</ref> Upon his last visit to church president [[John Taylor (Mormon)|John Taylor]], Watt said, "President Taylor, I want you to know that if anything happens to me before I am reinstated in the Church, it is your responsibility."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Stringham|first1=Ida|title=England's First "Mormon" Convert The Biography of George Darling Watt|pages=108, 109|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref>
Watt died in [[Kaysville, Utah|Kaysville]], [[Utah Territory]], at the age of 65, estranged from the LDS Church and its leaders. Watt's obituary describes him as "honest truthful and sincere although perhaps misguided being a self made man of strong character and exercising vast influence there is not a little in his career which is remarkable."<ref>''[[Salt Lake Herald]]'', 25 October 1881.</ref> Following his death, Taylor made a special trip to the home to say that he should be buried in his [[temple robes]].
Like many early Latter-day Saints, Watt practiced [[plural marriage]]; he had six wives. One of his wives, Jane Brown, was his half sister—they shared a mother, Mary Ann Wood.<ref name="PolygamyIncest">{{cite journal|last1=Embry|first1=Jessie L|title=Ultimate Taboos: Incest and Mormon Polygamy|journal=Journal of Mormon History|date=January 1, 1992|volume=18|issue=1|pages=93–113|url=http://digitalcommons.usu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1018&context=mormonhistory|accessdate=21 June 2017}}</ref>

'''George Kodinos''' or '''Codinus''' ({{lang-el|Γεώργιος Κωδινός}}), also '''[[Pseudepigrapha|Pseudo]]-Kodinos''', ''[[kouropalates]]'' in the [[Byzantine]] court, is the reputed 14th-century author of three extant works in late [[Byzantine literature]].
Their attribution to him is merely a matter of convenience, two of them being anonymous in the manuscripts. Οf Kodinos himself nothing is known; it is supposed that he lived towards the end of the 14th century. The works referred to are the following: #''[[Patria of Constantinople|Patria]]'' (Πάτρια Κωνσταντινουπόλεως), treating of the history, topography, and monuments of [[Constantinople]]. It is divided into five sections: (a) the foundation of the city; (b) its situation, limits and topography; (c) its statues, works of art, and other notable sights; (d) its buildings; (e) and the construction of the [[Hagia Sophia]]. It was written in the reign of [[Basil II]] (976-1025), revised and rearranged under [[Alexios I Komnenos]] (1081–1118), and perhaps copied by Codinus, whose name it bears in some (later) manuscripts. The chief sources are: the ''Patria'' of [[Hesychius of Miletus|Hesychius Illustrius of Miletus]], the anonymous ''[[Parastaseis syntomoi chronikai]]'', and an anonymous account ({{lang|grc|ἔκφρασις}}) of St Sophia (ed. [[Theodor Preger]] in ''Scriptores originum Constantinopolitanarum'', fasc. i, 1901, followed by the ''Patria'' of Codinus). [[Procopius]], ''De Aedificiis'' and the poem of [[Paulus Silentiarius]] on the dedication of St. Sophia should be read in connexion with this subject. #''De Officiis'' ({{lang|grc|Τακτικόν περί των οφφικίων του Παλατίου Kωνσταντινουπόλεως και των οφφικίων της Μεγάλης Εκκλησίας}}), a treatise, written in an unattractive style between 1347 and 1368, of the court and higher [[ecclesiastical]] dignities and of the ceremonies proper to different occasions, as they had evolved by the middle [[Palaiologan period]]. It should be compared with the earlier ''[[De Ceremoniis]]'' of [[Constantine Porphyrogenitus]] and other ''[[Taktika (disambiguation)|Taktika]]'' of the 9th and 10th centuries [https://books.google.de/books?id=udPOxVbiV70C&hl=el&pg=PP7#v=onepage&q&f=false]. #A chronological outline of events from the beginning of the world to the [[Fall of Constantinople]] to the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]] (called Agarenes in the manuscript title).
Complete editions are (by [[Immanuel Bekker]]) in the ''Bonn Corpus scriptorum Hist. Byz.'' (1839–1843, where, however, some sections of the ''Patria'' are omitted), and in [[Jacques Paul Migne|JP Migne]], ''[[Patrologia graeca]] civil.''; see also [[Karl Krumbacher]], ''Geschichte der byzantinischen Litteratur'' (1897).

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix = | name = Helen King | honorific_suffix = | image = 'Bodily Fluids Fluid Bodies in Greek and Roman Antiquity 32.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = King giving a keynote presentation at Cardiff University in 2016 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1957}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | discipline = [[Classics]] | sub_discipline = [[Ancient medicine]] | movement = | religion = | denomination = | education = | alma_mater = [[University College London]] | thesis_title = | workplaces = [[University of Reading]]
[[Open University]] | notable_works = | awards = }} '''Helen King''' (born 1957) is a British classical scholar. She is Professor Emerita of Classical Studies at the [[Open University]].{{cite web |url=http://www.open.ac.uk/people/hk2455 |title=Professor Helen King |work=OU people profiles |publisher=Open University |accessdate=29 August 2016 }} She was previously Professor of the History of Classical Medicine and Head of the Department of Classics at the [[University of Reading]].{{cite book|last=Erskine|first=Andrew|title=A companion to ancient history|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-Y_aM_74ENMC&pg=PR15|accessdate=5 March 2011|year=2009|publisher=John Wiley and Sons|isbn=978-1-4051-3150-6|page=15}} ==Early life and education== King was born in 1957. For King going to university or doing a PhD wasn't inevitable, and she had little notion of what doctoral research involved.{{Cite news|url=https://wcc-uk.blogs.sas.ac.uk/2016/08/15/my-classics-career-prof-helen-king/|title=My Classics Career: Prof. Helen King|date=2016-08-15|work=WCC-UK|access-date=2018-08-04|language=en-GB}} Nevertheless, she completed her first degree in Ancient History and Social Anthropology at [[University College London]]. She was awarded her doctorate in 1985 for a PhD on [[menstruation]] in [[ancient Greece]] supervised by Sally Humphreys.{{cite web |url=http://wcc-uk.blogs.sas.ac.uk/2016/08/15/my-classics-career-prof-helen-king/ |title=My Classics Career |first=Helen |last=King |publisher=Women's Classical Committee |date=15 August 2016 |accessdate=29 August 2016 }}{{Cite book|title=From 'parthenos' to 'gyne': the dynamics of category|last=King|first=Helen|publisher=PhD Thesis, University of London|year=1985|isbn=|location=|pages=5}} Her thesis was entitled ''From 'parthenos' to 'gyne': the Dynamics of Category.'' ==Academic career== [[File:'Bodily Fluids Fluid Bodies in Greek and Roman Antiquity 21.jpg|thumb|278x278px|Helen King delivering her keynote lecture, Cardiff University, 2016]] Having completed her doctorate, King held research fellowships at the universities of [[Cambridge University Press|Cambridge]] and [[Newcastle University|Newcastle]], taught at the [[Liverpool Institute of Higher Education]] for eight years, and moved to Reading on a [[Wellcome Trust]] University Award in 1996. From 2008 she was also Visiting Professor at the [[Peninsula Medical School]] in [[Truro]]. She moved to the Open University to assume the role of Professor of Classical Studies in 2011. She retired in January 2017 and took up the position of Robert E. and Susan T. Rydell Visiting Professor 2017–2018 at [[Gustavus Adolphus College]], St Peter, MN.{{Cite web|url=https://gustavus.edu/events/nobelconference/concertFiles/media/2017/Nobel_53_Program_2017.pdf|title=Nobel Conference 2017 Program|last=|first=|date=3 October 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} King was a Women's Studies Area Advisor to the [[Oxford Classical Dictionary]] (1996). She has been a Fellow at the Netherlands Institute for Advanced Studies (2001), a Landsdowne Visiting Lecturer at the [[University of Victoria]], British Columbia (2002), a Visiting Professor at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] (2005), a Käthe Leichter Visiting Professor in Women's Studies and Gender Studies at the University of Vienna (2014){{Cite web|url=https://genderausschuss.univie.ac.at/index.php?id=78116&L=0|title=Käthe-Leichter-GastprofessorInnen ab 1999|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 September 2018}} and Provost's Distinguished Women Lecturer, Notre Dame, IN (2016).{{Cite web|url=https://provost.nd.edu/diversity/provost-s-distinguished-women-lecturers/|title=Provost’s Distinguished Women Lecturers|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} King has appeared on ''[[History Cold Case]]'', ''Tony Robinson's Gods & Monsters'', and ''Harlots, Housewives & Heroines: A 17th Century History for Girls''.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3391707/?ref_=nv_sr_6 |title=Helen King |publisher=[[IMDb]] |accessdate=2017-02-22}} She has contributed to two episodes of [[In Our Time (radio series)]] on [[BBC Radio 4]], speaking on [[Galen]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b03c4dys|title=In Our Time, Galen|accessdate=2018-05-22}} and [[The Hippocratic Oath]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b014gdqq|title=In Our Time, The Hippocratic Oath|accessdate=2018-05-22}} == Research interests == With the publication of her book ''[[Hippocrates]]' Woman: Reading the Female Body in Ancient Greece'' (1998), King established herself as the leading authority on the practice and theory of [[History of medicine|ancient medicine]] as relating to women and how it continues to influence thought to the present day. She has published on the myths of [[Tithonos]],{{cite book|last=Davidson|first=James|title=The Greeks and Greek Love: A Bold New Exploration of the Ancient World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PijaG8n5Zz8C&pg=PA678|accessdate=5 March 2011|date=2009-05-26|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|isbn=978-0-375-50516-4|page=678}} on [[mermaid]]s,{{cite book|last=Cordingly|first=David|title=Seafaring Women: Adventures of Pirate Queens, Female Stowaways, and Sailors' Wives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xFtfx96d84UC&pg=PA265|accessdate=5 March 2011|date=2002-03-12|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|isbn=978-0-375-75872-0|page=265}} and on the myth/fable of [[Agnodice]], "the first midwife".{{Cite web|url=https://mistakinghistories.wordpress.com/2017/10/18/agnodice-reading-the-story/|title=Agnodice: reading the story|last=|first=|date=18 October 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} She has investigated how this story was used to give authority to women in medical roles in various historical periods.{{Cite book|title=The One-Sex Body on Trial|last=King|first=Helen|publisher=Routledge|year=2013|isbn=9781138247628|location=|pages=}} ==Professional contribution== King was a member of the [[General Synod of the Church of England]] from 1985 to 1993 and, as part of the 'Historical' thematic working group, is contributing to the Church's proposed teaching document on human sexuality.{{cite web |url=https://www.churchofengland.org/about/leadership-and-governance/general-synod/bishops/membership-episcopal-teaching-document-and-pastoral-advisory-group#na|title=Membership of the Episcopal Teaching Document and Pastoral Advisory Group|accessdate=2018-05-22}} [[File:Helen King - Greek and Roman Medicine.jpg|thumb|Front cover image of Helen King, Greek and Roman Medicine (2001)]] ==Select publications== * ''Hippocrates' Woman: Reading the Female Body in Ancient Greece'' (1998); {{ISBN|0415138957}}{{Cite web|url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2000/2000-07-20.html|title=Review of 'Hippocrates' Woman: Reading the Female Body in Ancient Greece'|accessdate=2018-05-22}} *''Greek and Roman Medicine'' (2001). {{ISBN|9781853995453}}{{Cite journal|last=Riddle|first=John M.|date=2004-06-15|title=Greek and Roman Medicine (review)|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/169366|journal=Bulletin of the History of Medicine|language=en|volume=78|issue=2|pages=465–466|doi=10.1353/bhm.2004.0096|issn=1086-3176}} *''The Disease of Virgins: Green Sickness, Chlorosis and the Problems of Puberty'' (2004); {{ISBN|0-203-48710-9}} * ''Health in Antiquity'' (2005); {{ISBN|9780415220651}}{{Cite web|url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2006/2006-08-15.html|title=Review of 'Health in Antiquity'|accessdate=2018-05-22}} * ''Midwifery, Obstetrics and the Rise of Gynaecology: The Uses of a Sixteenth-Century Compendium'' (2007); {{ISBN|9780754653967}} * ''Blood, Sweat and Tears: The Changing Concepts of Physiology from Antiquity into Early Modern Europe'' (with Manfred Horstmansoff and Claus Zittel 2012); {{ISBN|978-90-04-22918-1}}{{Cite web|url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2013/2013-09-55.html|title=Review of 'Blood, Sweat and Tears: The Changing Concepts of Physiology from Antiquity into Early Modern Europe'|accessdate=2018-05-22}} * ''La Médecine dans l' Antiquité grecque et romaine'' (with Véronique Dasen, 2008); {{ISBN|9782970053668}} * ''The One-Sex Body on Trial: The Classical and Early Modern Evidence'' (2013); {{ISBN|978-1-4094-6335-1}}{{Cite web|url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2014/2014-09-15.html|title=Review of 'The One-Sex Body on Trial: The Classical and Early Modern Evidence'|accessdate=2018-05-22}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{cite web|title=Helen King|url=https://open.academia.edu/HelenKing|publisher=The Open University - Academia.edu|language=en}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:King, Helen}} [[Category:Academics of Liverpool Hope University]] [[Category:Academics of the Open University]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Reading]] [[Category:Alumni of University College London]] [[Category:British historians]] [[Category:British women historians]] [[Category:English classical scholars]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Women classical scholars]] [[Category:Classical studies]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} '''Hernando del Pulgar''' (1436 – c. 1492) was a [[converso]] Spanish writer.
He was born at [[Pulgar]] (near [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]]) and was educated at the court of [[John II of Castile|John II]]. [[Henry IV of Castile|Henry IV]] made him one of his secretaries, and under [[Isabella I of Castile|Isabella]] he became councillor of state, was charged with a mission to France, and in 1482 was appointed [[historiographer]]-royal. He is said to have died in 1492.
His ''Crónica de los Reyes Católicos'', wrongly ascribed in the first edition (1545) to [[Antonio de Nebrija]], who had composed a Latin history based upon Pulgar's manuscript, is commonly supposed to be propaganda for his patrons, Queen Isabella and King Ferdinand; nevertheless, it is often critical of their policies and admonitory in its insistence that monarchs need to respect moral and spiritual ideals.<ref>David A. Boruchoff, "Historiography with License: Isabel, the Catholic Monarch and the Kingdom of God,” ''Isabel la Católica, Queen of Castile: critical essays'' (New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2003), 225–94.</ref> Pulgar's ''Claros varones de Castilla'' (1486), a series of portraits of eminent nobles, ecclesiastics, and men of learning, provides interesting insights into the court of Henry IV. These portraits were published together with Pulgar's ''Letras'' (1486), which were directed to both well-known and anonymous correspondents. Pulgar also composed a gloss (ca. 1485) on the ''Coplas de Mingo Revulgo''.
==References== {{Reflist}} * Boruchoff, David A. “Historiography with License: Isabel, the Catholic Monarch and the Kingdom of God.” ''Isabel la Católica, Queen of Castile: critical essays''. New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2003. 225-94.
