[[Battle of Mahidpur]] |awards= }} [[Major-general (United Kingdom)|Major-general]] '''Sir John Malcolm''' [[Order of Bath|GCB]], [[Order of the Lion and the Sun|KLS]] (2 May 1769 – 30 May 1833) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] soldier, [[diplomat]], [[East India Company]] administrator, [[politician|statesman]], and [[historian]]. ==Early life== Sir John Malcolm was born in 1769, one of seventeen children of George Malcolm, an impoverished tenant farmer in [[Eskdale, Dumfries and Galloway|Eskdale]] in the Scottish Border country, and his wife Margaret (‘Bonnie Peggy’), née [[Pasley]]. He left school, family and country at the age of thirteen, and achieved distinction in the [[East India Company]] over the next half century. A spirited character, he was nicknamed ‘Boy Malcolm’; for throughout his life he retained a youthful enthusiasm for field sports and fun and games. But behind this boisterous exterior lay serious intellectual ability and a considerable talent for government. ==Career== Arriving at [[Madras]] in 1783 as an ensign in the [[East India Company]]’s Madras Army, he served as a regimental soldier for eleven years, before spending a year in Britain to restore his health. He returned to India in 1795 as Military Secretary to General Sir [[Alured Clarke]], participating en route in Clarke’s capture of the [[Cape of Good Hope]]. In the Anglo-Mysore war of 1799 he served with the [[Hyderabad]] contingent, and later as joint secretary of the Peace Commission setting up the new government of [[Mysore]]. Later that year he was selected by the Governor-General ([[Lord Mornington]], later Marquess Wellesley) to lead a diplomatic mission to Iran. Following his return in 1801 he became Wellesley’s private secretary, based in [[Kolkata|Calcutta (Kolkata)]]. In the Anglo-Maratha war of 1803-05 he accompanied [[Sir Arthur Wellesley]] (later Duke of Wellington) as the Governor-General’s representative and diplomatic agent; the two men forming a lifelong friendship.Rory Muir. Wellington, The Path to Victory, 1769-1814 (2014), C H Philips, The Young Wellington in India (1973) In 1804 he was appointed British Resident at Mysore, but in 1805-6 saw further service in north India with General Lake. In early 1808 the Governor-General, [[Gilbert Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound, 1st Earl of Minto|Lord Minto]], sent him on a second mission to [[Iran]], but at this time French influence was dominant in [[Tehran]], and he was rebuffed. Later that year a separate mission from London under Sir Harford Jones arrived in Iran and achieved success, the Iran government having by then become disenchanted with the French. Malcolm was again sent to Iran in 1810, but by that time the British government had decided to conduct diplomatic relations with [[Iran]] directly from London, and appointed [[Sir Gore Ouseley]] as ambassador.R M Savory. British and French Diplomacy in Iran, 1808-1810. British Institute of Iran Studies (1972) In 1812 Malcolm returned to Britain for five years’ furlough, and spent much of his time as a writer, completing his ''History of Iran'' (the first in English derived directly from Iran sources) in 1815.A K S Lambton. Sir John Malcolm and the History of Iran. British Institute of Iran Studies (1995) For this he received an honorary DCL from the [[University of Oxford]]. Returning to India in 1817, he acted as the Governor-General’s agent in negotiations leading up to the third (and last) Anglo-Maratha war. He also acted as a general, leading Company troops to victory against Maharajah [[Holkar]] at the decisive battle of Mehidpoor (Mahidpur) in December 1817. In January 1818, Malcolm was placed by the [[Marquis of Hastings]] in the military and political charge of Central India (roughly, today’s [[Madhya Pradesh]]); during the four years he filled that station, his attention was directed to the object of collecting materials for the illustration of its past and present condition. The report hereof he sent to Calcutte, where it was printed by order of Government.Malcolm, Central India, Preface Disappointed to being superseded for the governorship of Bombay and Madras by his juniors, Malcolm left for Britain in 1822Parshotam Mehra: ''A Dictionary of Modern Indian History, 1707-1947''. Delhi. Bombay. Calcutta. Madras : OUP 1985, p.427-428, where he lived with his family as a country gentleman, completing two more books. In 1827 he was appointed Governor of [[Bombay]]. His governorship was generally successful, despite controversy over an unfortunate quarrel with the judges of the Bombay Supreme Court, who sought to extend their jurisdiction beyond Bombay to the [[Deccan Plateau|Deccan]] hinterland, newly acquired by the Company from the Maratha [[Peshwa]] of [[Poona]]. In seeking to end both [[sati (practice)|sati]] (the [[self-immolation]] of widows on their husband's funeral pyres) and female infanticide by moral persuasion, Malcolm visited [[Gujarat]] in February 1830 and met Sahajanand Swami, the founder of the [[Swaminarayan]] sect of Hinduism, who was advocating similar reforms. He has ever since been remembered in Swaminarayan literature.R Brady Williams. An Introduction to Swaminarayan Hinduism Cambridge (2001). Together with his predecessor, Mountstuart Elphinstone, he was a pioneer in the promotion of Indian education and the training of Indians for the higher ranks of government. He also served as president of the [[Asiatic Society of Bombay|Literary Society of Bombay]] In 1831 Malcolm finally returned to Britain, and immediately became a [[Member of Parliament]] for the rotten borough of [[Launceston (UK Parliament constituency)|Launceston]], supporting his friend the Duke of Wellington in opposition to the [[Reform Act 1832|Reform Bill]]. He bought [[Warfield Hall]] from the Parry family and busied himself renovating it. His last public act was a speech in April 1833 to the Proprietors (shareholders) of the East India Company, persuading them to accept the Government’s terms for renewal of its Charter. Immediately afterwards he suffered a stroke, and died on 30 May 1833. He was buried in [[St James's Church, Piccadilly]]. There are statues of Sir John Malcolm in [[Westminster Abbey]]'s north transept and in the Town Hall in Bombay. There is also a 100 foot high obelisk celebrating Malcolm’s achievements on the top of Whita Hill, above [[Langholm]] in Scotland. ==Family== In 1807 he married (in Mysore) Isabella Charlotte, the second daughter of General [[Sir Alexander Campbell, 1st Baronet|Sir Alexander Campbell]]. She bore five children, including [[George Alexander Malcolm]]. ==Legacy== [[Image:Malcolm Monument - geograph.org.uk - 1383313.jpg|thumb|200px|Malcolm Monument]] Together with his contemporaries [[Mountstuart Elphinstone]] and [[Sir Thomas Munro]], Malcolm was an architect of three early principles of British rule, whose wisdom “was too soon forgotten and remembered too late”. Four main themes can be identified. Firstly, India was to be ruled for the benefit of the Company – but also of Indians, i.e. no British settlers. Secondly, [[indirect rule]] was to be preferred, leaving existing Indian rulers in place wherever possible, with minimal disturbance of traditional methods of governance, religion and social structure. Thirdly, Malcolm helped to develop the role of the [[Colonial_Service#Ranks|District Officer]], a small group of powerful administrators with minimal overt force to support them. Fourthly, Malcolm promoted a ‘forward’ foreign policy; meaning diplomatic engagement with neighbouring states such as [[Iran]], [[Afghanistan]] and [[Central Asia]]. He was a mentor and inspiration to several celebrated Anglo-Indian statesmen – among them [[Henry Pottinger]], [[Charles Metcalfe, 1st Baron Metcalfe|Charles Metcalfe]], [[Alexander Burnes]] and [[Sir Henry Rawlinson, 1st Baronet|Henry Rawlinson]] ==Literary works== Malcolm wrote nine books, plus a volume of poetry, as follows: ''Sketch of the Sikhs'', 1812{{cite journal|title=Review of ''Sketch of the Sikhs'' by Brigadier-General Sir John Malcolm|journal=The Quarterly Review|date=July 1813|volume=9|pages=472–479|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=hvd.32044092624576;view=1up;seq=484}} [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001867734 ''Sketch of the Political History of India,''] 1811 ''Disturbances in the Madras Army in 1809,'' 1812 ''The History of Persia,'' 1815 [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/012155288 ''A Memoir of Central India,''] 1823 ''The Political History of India,'' 1826 [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/008730547 ''Sketches of Persia; this book is not written by Malcolm,but by one of his companions in his mission to Iran ;the writer remains anonymous and has introduced himself as the traveler ;he has referred to Malcolm in his text as ilchi ,which is a Persian word means envoy of a foreign country . ,''] 1827 [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/006658381 ''The Government of India,''] 1833 [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001251555 ''The Life of Robert, Lord Clive,''] 1836 (posthumous) ==References== {{refimprove|date=April 2015}} {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Harrington |first=Jack |year=2010 |title=Sir John Malcolm and the Creation of British India |location=New York |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan}} * {{cite book |last=Kaye |first=John W. |year=1856 |url=https://archive.org/details/lifecorresponden01kaye |title=The life and correspondence of Major-General Sir John Malcolm, G. [[José Luis García-López]] (artist) |species = Human |homeworld = |alliances = |partners = |supports = |aliases = Pharaoh |powers = |cat = super |subcat = DC Comics |hero = |villain = y |sortkey = King Tut (comics) }} '''King Tut''' is the name of different fictional characters in [[DC Comics]]. The first depiction of the character made his television debut in ''[[Batman (TV series)|Batman: The Curse of Tut]]'' (April 13, 1966). He was created by Earl Barret, Robert C. Dennis and Charles R. Rondeau, and portrayed by [[Victor Buono]]. In his memoir ''Back to the Batcave'', [[Adam West]] describes him as the only villain created for the TV series to be a real success. A second depiction of King Tut made his comic book debut in ''[[Batman Confidential]]'' No. 26, (April 2009), this version was created by [[Christina Weir]], [[Nunzio DeFilippis]] and [[José Luis García-López]]. ==Publication history== The character of King Tut started out on the [[Batman (TV series)|Batman]] television line episodes of the series' original run.https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0120658/filmoseries#tt0059968 King Tut recently made his debut in the [[DC Universe|DC Comics Universe]], appearing in the pages of ''[[Batman Confidential]]'' No. 26 (April 2009). ==Fictional character biography== ===Batman (TV series)=== King Tut began as Professor William Omaha McElroy (portrayed by [[Victor Buono]]), an Egyptologist at [[Yale University]]. After a blow to the head during a student riot, the Professor developed [[amnesia]] and thereafter believed he was a [[reincarnation]] of [[King Tut]]. He sought to take over [[Gotham City]] and defeat [[Batman]] and [[Dick Grayson|Robin]]. He was defeated by another blow to the head, returning him to his normal state. The pattern would follow for subsequent appearances—he would suffer a blow to the head, believe himself to be King Tut, fight Batman and Robin for control of Gotham City, only to suffer another blow to the head, which would return him to his [[real self]]. As such, he would be the only villain not to be jailed for his actions (the [[insanity defense]] would apply here). Completely cognizant of what happens during his states of [[amnesia]], Professor McElroy tried to prevent the personality switching by wearing a reinforced hat to prevent unwanted blows, but without success. King Tut attempted to release a handful of ancient [[Scarabaeidae|scarab]] [[beetles]] on Gotham City in the second season of the series. With the beetles in his possession, Tut would have the ability to create a terrible ancient potion called ''abu raubu simbu tu'', which can be used to subdue the human will. Tut planned on concocting 95,000 gallons of the drug, more than enough to put all of Gotham under his power. His first victim was the head of the Gotham City Police, Chief O'Hara, who Tut commanded to perform acrobatics on the ledge of a building. King Tut nearly succeeded in his sinister plot, having tricked Batman into taking the drug as well. However, Batman protected himself from the drug's hypnotic power by coating his [[stomach]] with [[buttermilk]]. While trying to escape, Tut accidentally swallowed the drug himself and became Batman's [[slave]], which allowed Batman and Robin to safely take King Tut to [[James Gordon (comics)|Commissioner Gordon]]'s office where he reverted to his normal self. In the episodes "King Tut's Coup" and "Batman's Waterloo," Professor McElroy is approached by two Yale students who ask him about his King Tut side. He tells them about it while he mentions that he had to wear a reinforced hat to prevent unwanted blows. The moment he shows off his hat, three flower pots hit the three of them on the head. While Professor McElroy became King Tut again, the two students develop the personalities of King Tut's Royal Jester and Lord Chancellor. Together with a female moll named Neila, they plotted to capture Lisa Carson. With help from Neila, Batman and Robin were able to get King Tut hit on the head again regressing him back to Professor McElroy. In "The Unkindliest Tut of All," it was mentioned by Commissioner Gordon to Batman that Professor McElroy was hit on the head by a brick while at a love-in. King Tut sets himself up as a crime predictor and even claims that Bruce Wayne is Batman. While claiming that there will be a raid on Gotham State Penitentiary to free all of its arch-criminals, King Tut targets a scroll that will take him to the statue of a god. With help from Batgirl, Batman and Robin defeat King Tut and his henchmen. While at the Gotham City Police Department, King Tut still claims that Batman is Bruce Wayne when Commissioner Gordon gets a call from a beat cop that Louie the Lilac was sighted. In his final appearance in the series titled "I'll Be a Mummy's Uncle," King Tut gets out of his therapy lesson and buys a plot of land adjacent to [[Wayne Manor]] as part of a plan to obtain a rare mineral. The villain tunneled beneath the manor and accidentally discovered the subterranean [[Batcave]]. He realized that Batman and Bruce Wayne were the same person. Batman and Robin then battled Tut and his henchmen in the Batcave. The Dynamic Duo administered a drug spray to the henchmen that would erase their recent memory. Tut, however, fled to the surface via the tunnel after all the spray ran out from the can. Once at the top of the tunnel, Tut was about to reveal his discovery of the Batcave—and Batman's true identity of Bruce Wayne—to [[James Gordon (comics)|Commissioner Gordon]], when Batman provoked Tut to raise his voice, thereby causing a rock to fall on his head, knocking him out. When Tut regained consciousness, he was once again Prof. McElroy, with no memories of Batman's secret identity. Seeing that he is late for his class, Professor McElroy runs off with Commissioner Gordon and Chief O'Hara still asking who Batman is. King Tut later popped up in "The Entrancing Dr. Cassandra" yet a body double (Guy Way) was portraying King Tut at the time. He alongside [[Joker (character)|Joker]], [[Riddler]], [[Penguin (character)|Penguin]], [[Catwoman]], and [[Egghead (DC Comics)|Egghead]] were freed from Gotham State Penitentiary by Dr. Cassandra Spellcraft and Cabala. When explaining her plans to rule Gotham City, she gives King Tut the job to rob the museums. The villains were defeated by Batman, Robin, and Batgirl. Tut's hideouts sometimes included an "[[apothecary]]", the only one in Gotham, in the "Pyramid" building. ===Comics=== The comic book version of King Tut is shown to be Victor Goodman, a criminal [[Egyptology|Egyptologist]] who targets and murders wealthy citizens, and leaves Egyptian-themed riddles, similar to the [[Riddle of the Sphinx]]. Batman teams up with the [[Riddler]], who does not appreciate his [[modus operandi]] being stolen, and agrees to help to stop Goodman. They managed to defeat King Tut who is sent to prison until he is transferred to [[Arkham Asylum]].As seen in ''Batman Confidential'' #26–28, (April–June 2009) His alter-ego is an homage to actor Victor Buono. ==In other media== ===Television=== King Tut appears on ''[[Batman: The Brave and the Bold]]'' voiced by [[John DiMaggio]]. Due to copyright issues with FOX, King Tut is referred to in the synopsis as "Pharaoh". In "Day of the Dark Knight!", he is shown as a convict trying to escape [[Iron Heights Penitentiary]], but was foiled by Batman and [[Green Arrow]]. The other convicts that Tut escapes with are either common criminals, the show's supervillains, or other villains from the Adam West series (including [[Egghead (Batman)|Egghead]], The Bookworm, Archer, Louie The Lilac and Shame who are recognized both by face features and their trademark hats). Tut makes another jailbreak cameo at [[Blackgate Penitentiary]] in "Night of the Huntress!". In "Battle of the Superheroes!", Batman and Robin wear special mummified suits in order to fight Pharaoh when he uses a special staff to turn people into zombies that obey his every command (The wrappings are coated in buttermilk, another reference to the live-action Batman series). With some pictures taken by [[Vicki Vale]], Batman and Robin managed to defeat Pharaoh and freed his victims. ===Film=== * The William McElroy version of King Tut appears in ''[[Batman: Return of the Caped Crusaders]]''. He is among the villains that Robin and [[Catwoman]] recruited to help fight an evilized Batman after the two of them sprung King Tut and the villains from Gotham State Penitentiary. * The William McElroy version of King Tut appears in ''[[The Lego Batman Movie]]''. He is among the villains that assist Joker in his attacks on Gotham City. * The William McElroy version of King Tut appears in ''[[Batman vs. Two-Face]]'', voiced by [[Wally Wingert]]. ==See also== * [[List of Batman Family enemies]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0519516/ IMDB: Batman, The Curse of Tut] * [https://www.imdb.com/character/ch0117633/filmoseries#tt0059968 IMDB: King Tut, Character Filmography] * [http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/WF/sections/backstage/unused/batman/tut.php King Tut Animated] Sketch and info available. * [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/Hollywood/Hills/7537/tut.htm&date=2009-10-25+08:07:38 The 1966 Batman TV Villains – Victor Buono] {{1966-1968 Batman television series}} [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 2009]] [[Category:Fictional historians]] [[Category:DC Comics supervillains]]

'''Margarita Tacheva''' ({{lang-bg|Маргарита Тачева}}) (June 4, 1936 – December 18, 2008) was an eminent [[Bulgaria]]n [[historian]], a full professor in [[ancient history]] and [[Thracology]].
== Selected publications == * ''The kings of ancient Thrace'', book 1. Sofia, 2006. * ''Ancient history of the Bulgarian lands in Hellenistic and Roman times''. Sofia, 1987, 1997 (second edition). * ''Eastern Cults in Moesia Inferior and Thracia: (5th Century BC-4th Century AD)''. Leiden, 1983. https://books.google.com/books?id=NtQUAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&hl=bg
== References == Academic career — https://web.archive.org/web/20091019212054/http://www.clio.uni-sofia.bg/tacheva/index.html
Curriculum vitae — http://www.history.swu.bg/PDF/cv.pdf
List of selected publications — https://web.archive.org/web/20101128160934/http://www.clio.uni-sofia.bg/tacheva/BMT.pdf
Bibliography of Proff. Dr. Margarita Tacheva, Dr. Litt. — http://www.history.swu.bg/PDF/1.pdf
{{Authority control}}

Sancti Hieronymi Croatorum {{la icon}} | image=Campo Marzio - san Girolamo degli Schiavoni 00523.JPG| caption=[[Saint Jerome]] of the [[Croats]] | location= {{flagicon|Italy}} [[Rome]], [[Italy]] | religious_affiliation= [[Roman Catholic]] | rite= | province=Rome | district=Lazio | consecration_year= 1587 | status= [[Titular church]] | leadership= [[Josip Bozanic]] | architect= | architecture_type= [[Church (building)|Church]] | architecture_style= | specifications= | facade_direction= | groundbreaking= 1585 | year_completed=1587 | construction_cost= | capacity= | length= | width= | width_nave= | height_max= | materials= }} '''[[Saint Jerome]] of the [[Croats]]''' is the national Catholic church of [[Croatia]] on Via Tomacelli in the [[Campus Martius]] of [[Rome]]. It is now a chapel of the [[Pontifical Croatian College of Saint Jerome]] in Rome and is only open to visitors by arrangement with the College. [[File:San Girolamo degli Schiavoni.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Frontal section]] ==Name== It is also known as "St. Jerome of the [[South Slavs|Illyrians]]" ({{lang-it|San Girolamo degli Illirici}}), and was formerly known as "St. Jerome of the Slavs" ({{lang-it|San Girolamo degli [[Schiavone|Schiavoni]]}}). It changed its name after [[Croatia]] gained independence from [[Socialist Republic of Croatia|Yugoslavia]] in 1991. ==History== It was first built in 1585-1587 for refugees from areas ruled by the [[Ottoman Empire|Turks]], and dedicated to St Jerome, who was from [[Dalmatia]] (former Roman "[[Illyricum (Roman province)|Illyricum]]").[http://www.romaspqr.it/ROMA/Chiese_rinascimentali/interno_s_girolamo_degli_illirici.htm Interior of San Girolamo degli illirici] The site had been given to them in 1453 (the year of the [[Fall of Constantinople]]) by [[Pope Nicholas V]], for the construction of a [[Hospice care|hospice]]. {{About|the garment}} {{For|The Royal Teens song|Short Shorts}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} [[File:MARIANA_DE_MELO.JPG|thumb|Two people wearing shorts. (Argentina, 2011)]]
'''Shorts''' are a [[garment]] worn over the [[human pelvis|pelvic]] area, circling the [[waist]] and splitting to cover the upper part of the legs, sometimes extending down to the knees but not covering the entire length of the [[leg]]. They are called "shorts" because they are a shortened version of [[trousers]], which cover the entire leg, but not the foot. Shorts are typically worn in warm weather or in an environment where comfort and air flow are more important than the protection of the legs.
There are a variety of shorts, ranging from knee-length short trousers that can in some situations be worn as formal clothes to [[beachwear]] and athletic shorts. Some types of shorts are typically worn by women, such as [[culotte]]s, which are a divided [[skirt]] resembling a pair of loose-cut shorts.
==Terminological differences== In British English the term "short trousers" has been used, but only for shorts that are a short version of real{{clarify|date=November 2015}} trousers (pants), e.g. tailored shorts, often lined, as typically worn as part of [[school uniform]] for boys up to their early teens,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/short-trousers |title= Short trousers |publisher= Oxford Dictionary}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/history/making_history/makhist10_prog3c.shtml |title= Short trousers for boys |publisher= BBC History}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://ppparchive.durham.gov.uk/photos/picviewer.asp?previous=1550&submit.x=37&submit.y=48 |title= People past and present |publisher= Durham County Council Archives}}</ref> and by servicemen and policemen in tropical climates. The American term "short pants" is probably the nearest equivalent in the US, there they might now be called "dress shorts", a term that has not gained much currency in Britain. A somewhat similar garment worn by men in Australia is called "[[Stubbies (brand)|stubbies]]". "Shorts" is used unqualified in British English to refer to sports shorts, athletic shorts, or casual shorts: the last is nowadays commonplace in warm weather in the UK.
The term "boxer shorts" was an American coinage for a particular kind of men's [[underwear]], and is now common in Britain. However, boxer shorts are often referred to as "boxers" in the USA. The word "pants" refers to outerwear (trousers) in American usage (except when modified to "[[underpants]]") but when used unqualified in British English generally means underwear.
== Sociology == {{Refimprove section|date=July 2015}}
=== Europe and America === {{multiple image|perrow = 2|total_width=300 | image1 = Leaders welcoming boy into Mexico Scouting.jpg | image2 = Prostitute tj.jpg | footer = Two photos of Mexico: [[Scouting|Boy Scouts]] (''left'') and woman (''right'') wearing different types of shorts. }}
In much of Europe and the Americas during the 19th and early 20th centuries, shorts were worn as outerwear only by young boys until they reached a certain height or maturity. When boys got older, typically around puberty, they would receive their first pair of long trousers. This produced the perception that shorts were only for young boys. Because of this, men would not wear shorts to avoid looking immature. Women tended not to wear shorts in most cultures, due to social mores: they were expected to wear [[dress]]es, or [[skirt]]s and [[blouse]]s.
In the 1890s, knee pants (an early type of short pants) became the standard wear for American boys. Many urban school portraits from the 1890s show all but the oldest boys wearing knee pants.<ref>[http://histclo.com/schun/country/us/is/chron/19/us-isc1890.html U.S. School Clothes: Individual Schools--The 1890s] at Boys' Historical Clothing School Uniform Pages.</ref> North American boys normally wore knee pants with short stockings.<ref>[http://histclo.com/Country/us/gar/pants/knee/us-pantk.html North America Boys Garments: Pants--Knee Pants] at Boys' Historical Clothing School Uniform Pages.</ref> This began to change after the 1900s when North American boys began wearing [[knickerbockers (clothing)|knickerbockers]], while short pants became more popular in Europe. In the 1930s, shorts started to be worn for casual comfort (e.g. outdoor and athletic activities) by both men and women. However, it was still taboo to wear shorts outside certain activities.
Since about the time of [[The First World War]], when many soldiers served in tropical locations, adult men have worn shorts more often, especially in summer weather, but the perception of shorts as being only for young boys took several decades to change, and to some extent still exists in certain circles. By the late 20th century however it became common for men to wear shorts as casual wear in summer.
However, in many countries there are few formal settings where wearing shorts would be acceptable, as they are considered [[casual wear]]. Notable exceptions where men may wear short trousers to the office or at a formal gathering are South Africa, Bermuda, Australia and New Zealand. Since the 1990s, casual office dress has grown to include formal shorts in some U.K. and U.S. businesses, but by no means universally.
=== Worldwide === Adults are also commonly seen wearing shorts, however wearing shorts is less common among women in traditional eastern countries than in the West, although this varies widely by region - women more often wear shorts in large, cosmopolitan cities. In some countries adult women can be seen wearing loose-fitting shorts that end at or just below the knee, as these are seen as sufficiently modest.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/sections/npr-history-dept/2015/04/07/397804245/when-wearing-shorts-was-taboo When wearing shorts was taboo in USA -by www.npr.org ]</ref>
== Styles == {| class="wikitable" ! Image ! Name ! Description |- | [[File:Brazil vs. Chile in Mineirão 05.jpg|100px]] | '''Baggies''' | Loose-fitting shorts which reach the knees. This particular style has been associated with [[football kit]] and similar sports since 1904, when [[the Football Association]] of England dropped its rule requiring players cover their knees.<ref name=davies51/> Loose-fitting longer shorts rapidly replaced the former knickerbockers.<ref name=davies51>{{cite book |last=Davies| first=Hunter| title=Boots, Balls and Haircuts: An Illustrated History of Football from Then to Now |chapter=Chapter 3. Equipment: Bring on the Balls |page=51}}</ref> Until the 1960s, footballers referred to these garments as "knickers," but after the 1960s, the term "shorts" entered standard usage.<ref name=davies51/> During the 1970s and 1980s, much shorter shorts became standard wear for footballers, but following the adoption of longer shorts by [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.]] for a match on 18 May 1991, despite initial mockery, the longer length became more widely worn again.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/English_Football_League/FA_Cup_Finals/1990-1999.html|title=English FA Cup Finalists 1990–1999 |publisher=HistoricalFootballKits.co.uk|accessdate=15 January 2008}}</ref> A popular nickname for [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion football club]] since the early 1900s has been the "Baggies." This is sometimes assumed to be in reference to the players' shorts, although there are multiple alternative explanations.<ref name=boing>{{cite web| title = Why are we called The Baggies? |url=http://www.baggies.com/faq/#BAGGIES |publisher=BOING |accessdate =11 November 2007}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book| last=McOwan | first=Gavin | title=The Essential History of West Bromwich Albion | publisher=Headline | year=2002 |pages=38–40 | isbn=0-7553-1146-9 }}</ref>
"Baggies" is also an alternative term for boardshorts (see below).<ref name=maurer/><ref name=schmidt159/> |- | [[File:Claude Froidevaux (1990) by Erling Mandelmann.jpg|100px]] | '''[[Bermuda shorts]]''' | [[File:Yellow Bermuda shorts.jpg|thumb|100px|Yellow Bermuda shorts]] Short trousers, terminating three to four inches above the knee, commonly worn by men in [[Bermuda]] (with knee-socks and a blazer and tie) for business attire and even at cocktail parties.<ref name=purcell>{{cite book |last1=Purcell |first1=Carl |last2=Purcell |first2=Ann |editor1-last=Zenfell |editor1-first=Martha Ellen |title=Bermuda: Volume 217 of the ''Insight Guides''|date=1991|publisher=Apa Publications |page=190}}</ref><ref name=bermuda>{{cite web |last1=Forbes |first1=Keith Archibald |title=Bermuda Shorts |url=http://www.bermuda-online.org/shorts.htm |website=Bermuda Online |accessdate=20 December 2015}}</ref> They are available in a wide range of colors, ranging from conservative grey and navy, to brighter hues such as orange, green and pink.<ref name=bermuda/> Despite their name, they are not of Bermudian origin, but were originally designed around 1900 for military wear by the British armed forces in tropical climates.<ref name=bermuda/> From the 1920s onwards these military uniform shorts began to be copied by Bermudian tailors and civilians, and were subsequently taken up by tourists who spread the style around the world.<ref name=bermuda/> The tourists who appropriated the style wore Bermuda shorts almost exclusively as casual wear.<ref name=bermuda/>
In the early 1990s Bermuda shorts became accepted in France as a fashionable option for women, although since the 1930s they had been increasingly established as an option for American women's [[sportswear (fashion)|fashionable sportswear]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Green |first1=Nancy L. |title=Ready-to-wear and ready-to-work : a century of industry and immigrants in Paris and New York |date=1997 |publisher=Duke University Press |location=Durham |isbn=9780822318743 |pages=105–135 |chapter=Bermuda Shorts in Comparative Perspective}}</ref><ref name=clemente>{{cite book|last1=Clemente|first1=Deirdre|title=Dress casual : how college students redefined American style|date=2014|publisher=UNC Press Books|isbn=9781469614076|pages=116–121|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TpjlAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA116|chapter=In the Gym}}</ref> In America, despite widespread criticism, Bermuda shorts were taken up by male and female students on college campuses from the 1920s and 1930s onwards, and by the 1950s, were widely worn.<ref name=clemente/> In early 21st century America, women's Bermuda shorts are known as "city shorts," and are usually knee-length, resembling a [[pencil skirt]].<ref name=bermuda/> |- | [[File:Beach boy summer time 2009.jpg|100px]] | '''[[Boardshorts]]''' | Boardshorts are a form of long, loose-fitting shorts specifically designed for beachwear and [[aquatic sports]]. They may also be described as "baggies" (see above) or "jams".<ref name=maurer>{{cite book |last1=Maurer |first1=Tracy Nelson |title=Surfing |date=2003 |publisher=Rourke Pub. |location=Vero Beach, Fla.|isbn=9781589522800 |page=21}}</ref><ref name=schmidt159>{{cite book |last1=Schmidt |first1=Christine |title=The swimsuit : fashion from poolside to catwalk |date=2012 |publisher=Berg |location=London |isbn=9780857851253|pages=159–160|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UPg5YQw5qBkC&pg=PT159}}</ref> As "surf trunks" they first emerged in Hawaii in the 1950s, distinguished by their construction which included [[fly (clothing)|fly fastenings]] and secure pockets with sealable flaps.<ref name=honolulu>{{cite book |last1=Moran |first1=Malie |last2=Pohlmann |first2=Attila |last3=Reilly |first3=Andrew |title=Honolulu street style |date=2014 |publisher=Intellect |location=Bristol |isbn=9781783203079 |pages=61–62 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pFt5AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT61}}</ref> These early surf trunks were made from cotton, although quick-drying synthetics such as [[nylon]] and [[neoprene]] quickly found favour with wearers.<ref name=honolulu/> They were made knee-length in order to protect the surfer's legs from sticking to the wax on their surfboard.<ref name=honolulu/>
In 1970 the company [[Quiksilver]] offered a highly successful boardshort design that rapidly gained a reputation among surfers as the best to be had.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Everist |first1=Richard |title=The complete guide to the Great Ocean Road : walks, beaches, heritage, ecology, towns and sustainable tourism through southwest Victoria |date=2009 |publisher=Best Shot! |location=Torquay, Vic. |isbn=9780975602348 |page=99 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G-t3d-aUoVkC&pg=PA99}}</ref> They would later pioneer a line of boardshorts specifically designed for the female wearer.<ref name=schmidt159/> Other leading boardshort manufacturers include [[Billabong (clothing)|Billabong]] and [[Rip Curl]].<ref name=schmidt159/>
By 2010, the boardshort was widely worn as a fashionable garment beyond the beach, including as [[clubwear]] and in schools.<ref name=honolulu/> In the early 21st century, polyester is increasingly used, often blended with other fibres such as Lycra, elastane, or spandex, creating an [[ultrasuede]] effect.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Staff writer|title=The best boardshorts for surfers in the world |url=http://www.surfertoday.com/surfing/7450-the-best-boardshorts-for-surfers-in-the-world |website=SurferToday.com |publisher=www.surfertoday.com |accessdate=8 April 2016}}</ref> |- |[[File:Boxer shorts on Jay Hieron.jpg|100px]] | '''[[Boxer shorts]] ''' | [[File:John Quinlan In Raja Boxing.jpg|thumb|100px|Wrestler [[John Quinlan (wrestler)|John Quinlan]] in boxing shorts (2010)]] Elastic-waisted soft fabric shorts usually worn as underwear, but originally designed for wear by [[boxing]] participants. In their current form "boxers" were introduced in 1925 by Jacob Golomb (founder of the sports equipment and clothing company [[Everlast (boxing)|Everlast]]) as an alternative to the leather-belted trunks that [[boxers]] typically wore.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kroessler|first1=Jeffrey A. |title=The greater New York sports chronology |date=2010 |publisher=Columbia University Press |location=New York |isbn=9780231518277 |page=100 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A2UaAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA100}}</ref> They subsequently became an alternative to [[long underwear]] as well.<ref name=riess>{{cite book |last1=Riess |first1=Steven A. |title=Sports in America from Colonial Times to the Twenty-First Century: An Encyclopedia |date=2015 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781317459477 |page=257 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DnCsBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA257}}</ref> Men's boxers as undergarments began to be presented in novelty prints and patterns from the late 1950s onwards.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Werlin |first1=Katy |editor1-last=Blanco F. |editor1-first=José |editor2-last=Hunt-Hurst |editor2-first=Patricia Kay |editor3-last=Lee |editor3-first=Heather Vaughan |display-editors = 3 |editor4-last=Doering |editor4-first=Mary |title=Clothing and Fashion: American Fashion from Head to Toe |date=2015 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=9781610693103 |page=199 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hDkVCwAAQBAJ&pg=RA3-PA199 |chapter=Men's Dress and Fashion 1946-1960}}</ref> During the 1980s and 1990s women began to wear boxer shorts paired with T-shirts as loungewear or sleepwear.<ref name=blanco299>{{cite book|editor1-last=Blanco F. |editor1-first=José |editor2-last=Hunt-Hurst |editor2-first=Patricia Kay |editor3-last=Lee |editor3-first=Heather Vaughan |display-editors = 3 |editor4-last=Doering |editor4-first=Mary |title=Clothing and Fashion: American Fashion from Head to Toe |date=2015 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=9781610693103 |page=199 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hDkVCwAAQBAJ&pg=RA3-PA199 |chapter=Underwear, 1980-Present}}</ref> [[Boxer briefs]], which emerged in the 1990s, are an underwear-specific variation on boxer shorts, but made from elastic knit fabric for a snug fit.<ref name=cole>{{cite book |last1=Cole |first1=Shaun |title=The Story of Men's Underwear |date=2012 |publisher=Parkstone International|location=New York|isbn=9781780428826|page=118|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EEEmuePeDX4C&pg=PA118}}</ref> |- |[[File:Woman In Boyshorts.jpg|100px]] | '''[[Boyshorts]] ''' | Boyshorts (or boy shorts) are a form of women's underwear that first emerged in the 1990s, closely resembling abbreviated hotpants (see below).<ref name=stalder>{{cite book |last1=Stalder |first1=Erika |title=Fashion 101 a crash course in clothing |date=2008 |publisher=Zest Books |location=San Francisco, CA |isbn=9780547946931 |page=110 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uNxhd1Z7n1EC&pg=PA110}}</ref> They are cut with wide sides and a low rise, reducing the risk of [[panty line|visible panty line]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Apsan |first1=Rebecca |last2=Stark |first2=Sarah |title=Lessons in lingerie finding your perfect shade of seduction |date=2012 |publisher=Workman Publishing |location=New York |isbn=9780761175018 |page=87|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tS9T3Xf5B_gC&pg=PA87}}</ref> Boyshorts are increasingly being worn as outerwear in sporting contexts, such as by [[Serena Williams]] on the tennis court,<ref name=stalder/> or by female athletes and runners as an alternative to "bun-huggers" (see below).<ref name=gerweck>{{cite journal|last1=Gerweck|first1=Jim|title=Going Any Length: The Long & Short of Running Shorts|journal=Running Times|date=May 2007|pages=46–48|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DMYDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA46}}</ref> |- |[[File:Womens beach volleyball.jpg|100px]] | '''Bun huggers ''' | Bun-huggers is a popular name for very brief, tight unisex athletic shorts, also known as "racing briefs." They have been compared to bikini bottoms.<ref name=gerweck/><ref name=oppliger/> In 2008 it was noted that the [[Fédération Internationale de Volleyball|International Volleyball Federation]] used to require that female [[volleyball]] players wear such garments while playing.<ref name=oppliger>{{cite book |last1=Oppliger |first1=Patrice A. |title=Girls Gone Skank: The Sexualization of Girls in American Culture |date=2008 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=9780786486502 |page=183 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c77ABgAAQBAJ&pg=PA183}}</ref><ref name=wsf>{{cite web|title=Bun Huggers: To Wear or Not to Wear |url=http://66.40.5.5/Content/Articles/Issues/Body-and-Mind/B/Bun-Huggers--To-Wear-or-Not-to-Wear.aspx |publisher=Women's Sports Foundation |date=2006}}{{dead link|date=December 2015}} Cited in Oppliger.</ref> Although it is argued and claimed that bun-huggers enable wearers to move unhindered and enjoy a wide range of movement, wearers and observers have expressed discomfort with their increasing skimpiness.<ref name=gerweck/><ref name=oppliger/> A study made by the [[Women's Sports Foundation]] commented that making such garments compulsory for women athletes was "venturing into the arena of athlete exploitation".<ref name=wsf/> Since the mid-2000s such garments are increasingly being replaced by boyshorts (see above) which offer increased coverage and security to their wearers.<ref name=gerweck/> |- |[[File:Man wearing a green T-shirt and cargo shorts (cropped).jpg|100px]] | '''[[Cargo shorts]] ''' | Cargo shorts are an abbreviated version of [[cargo pants]], typically around knee-length, with multiple pockets that are typically stitched to the outside sides of the legs. In 1980 cargo shorts were marketed as ideal for the sportsman or fisherman, with the pocket flaps ensuring that pocket contents were secure and unlikely to fall out.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Paulson|first1=F. M.|title=Boating: What's New on the Waterfront|journal=Field & Stream|date=March 1980|page=90|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0lo3xA96lTUC&pg=PA90}}</ref> By the mid-to-late 1990s cargo shorts found popularity among mainstream men's fashion.<ref>Hong, Nicole [https://www.wsj.com/articles/nice-cargo-shorts-youre-sleeping-on-the-sofa-1470082856 Nice Cargo Shorts! You’re Sleeping on the Sofa] ''Wall Street Journal''. 3 August 2016</ref> In 2012, [[Tim Gunn]] observed that while the pockets were undeniably useful for carrying things for work or other everyday tools, cargo shorts were more practical than elegant.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Gunn |first1=Tim |last2=Calhoun |first2=Ada |title=Tim Gunn's fashion bible : the fascinating history of everything in your closet|date=2012|publisher=Gallery Books|location=New York |isbn=9781451643862 |page=96 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pWG9AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA96}}</ref> |- | [[File:Culotte skirt and interior view.jpg|100px]] | '''[[Culottes]] ''' | Culottes were introduced in the mid-20th century as an abbreviated version of the late-nineteenth century divided skirt intended for horse- and bicycle-riding. Although called ''culotte skirts'', they are basically full shorts constructed to hide their division.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Yarwood |first1=Doreen |title=Illustrated encyclopedia of world costume |date=2011 |publisher=Dover Publications, Inc. |location=Mineola, N.Y. |isbn=9780486433806 |page=376 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UdP_sSKIxf0C&pg=PA376}}</ref> Since the mid-20th century culottes have been increasingly offered as an alternative to skirts in women's uniforms, for instance in the [[Vietnam War]] when female [[Red Cross]] workers found their uniform skirts impractical around helicopters.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Koureas |first1=Gabriel |editor1-last=Carden-Coyne |editor1-first=Ana |title=Gender and Conflict Since 1914: Historical and Interdisciplinary Perspectives |date=2012 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |isbn=9781137030276 |page=145 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2vccBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA145 |chapter=Militarization, Sexuality, and Red Cross Donut Dollies in the Vietnam War}}</ref> |- | [[File:Man wearing cutoffs.jpg|100px]] | {{Anchor|Cut-offs}}'''Cut-offs''' | Also called "cutoffs." A generic term for trousers where the legs have been cut off mid-way. The concept has been around since the 1930s when shorts began to be acceptable wear outside the sports field.<ref name=clemente/> During the 1960s and 1970s the concept of deliberately cutting off the legs of jeans, allowing the raw edge to fray, along with other means of customising them, took hold as part of Western youth culture.<ref name=regan>{{cite book|last1=Regan|first1=C.|editor1-last=Paul|editor1-first=Roshan|title=Denim: Manufacture, Finishing and Applications |date=2015 |publisher=Elsevier |isbn=9780857098498 |pages=203–204 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qZCuAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA203 |chapter=Role of denim and jeans in the fashion industry}}</ref> Whilst cut-offs can be home-made from existing jeans, ready-made cut-offs are also commercially retailed.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Aiglon|first1=Kelly|title=The long and short of cutoff jeans|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-07-05/entertainment/0707040358_1_cutoffs-fringe-jeans|accessdate=23 December 2015|work=The Chicago Tribune|publisher=Tribune Publishing|date=5 July 2007}}</ref> Extremely short denim cut-offs are known as "Daisy Dukes" (see below).<ref name=daisy/> |- | [[File:Cycling shorts (cropped from Cycling Ascent.jpg).jpg|100px]] | '''[[Cycling shorts]] ''' | [[File:Cycling Bibshorts (cropped).jpg|thumb|100px|Bib shorts]] Cycling shorts are skin-tight long shorts specifically designed for wear by cyclists to reduce chafing. While often elastic-waisted, a popular alternative style with integral [[suspenders]], more comfortable in the longer term for serious cyclists, is called ''bib shorts''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bicycling.com/bikes-and-gear-features/how/how-buy-bib-shorts|title=How to Buy Bib Shorts |last=Cross |first=Kim |work=[[Bicycling (magazine)|Bicycling]] |date=24 July 2013 |accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> They are designed to fit the posture of a cyclist bent over in the racing position, cut longer in the back than in the front to guarantee full coverage.<ref name=goodman>{{cite magazine |last1=Goodman |first1=Susan |title=Active Wear|magazine=New York Magazine|date=24 April 1989 |pages=113–115 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d-gCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA113 |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> Since the 1980s, such garments are increasingly designed to take into account the difference between male and female bodies, as women's shorts require a longer waist-to-crotch measurement.<ref name=goodman/>
Since the 1980s, 'bike shorts' have also been worn as fashion garments, although these versions often lack the internal padding and construction required by cyclists.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Gunn |first1=Tim |last2=Calhoun |first2=Ada |title=Tim Gunn's fashion bible : the fascinating history of everything in your closet |date=2012 |publisher=Gallery Books |location=New York |isbn=9781451643862 |page=209 |edition=1st Gallery Books hardcover|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pWG9AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA209}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Armijo |first1=Vic |title=The complete idiot's guide to cycling|date=1999|publisher=Alpha Books|location=New York, N.Y. |isbn=9781101198728 |edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w4cYE5flGIMC&pg=PT252}}</ref> |- | [[File:Daisy Dukes.jpg|100px]] | {{Anchor|Daisy Dukes}}'''[[Daisy Duke#Appearance|Daisy Dukes]]''' | An extremely short version of denim cut-offs, popularly known as Daisy Dukes, in reference to [[Catherine Bach]]'s character of that name from the American television show ''[[The Dukes of Hazzard]]''.<ref name=daisy>{{cite news |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3VYuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QdoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4352,2540768&dq=catherine+bach&hl=en |title= Catherine Bach Defends the Dukes |work =Beaver County Times |agency=UPI |location= Beaver, PA |accessdate=18 December 2015 |date=11 October 1981}}</ref> They are a form of hot pants or short shorts worn by women (see below). |- | [[File:Young man wearing jorts (denim shorts) (cropped).jpg|100px]] | '''Denim shorts ''' ''or'' {{anchor|Jorts}}'''Jorts''' |Denim shorts are worn by both genders. They can also be called "jorts", a [[portmanteau]] of "jeans" and "shorts," although this term is arguably applied to knee-length baggy styles.<ref name=lefler>{{cite book |last1=Lefler |first1=Anna |title=The chicktionary from A-line to Z-snap, the words every woman should know |date=2011 |publisher=Adams Media |location=Avon, Mass. |isbn=9781440531231 |page=106 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aRLhLxBl7tEC&pg=PA106}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Kovanis|first1=Georgea|title=On Style: Jorts: Tacky, or trendy or both?|url=http://www.freep.com/story/life/shopping/georgea-kovanis/2015/05/26/jorts-tacky-trendy/27985695/|accessdate=1 January 2016|agency=Detroit Free Press|date=27 May 2015}}</ref>
However, the term can describe many styles of shorts made from denim,<ref name=lefler/> such as cut-offs (see above), or Daisy Dukes (see above).<ref name=daisy/> The term "jorts," defined simply as denim shorts, was added to the Oxford English Dictionary in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Price|first1=Leslie|title=Oxford English Dictionary Adds Flatforms, Jorts, Double Denim.|url=http://www.racked.com/2013/8/28/7652021/oxford-english-dictionary-adds-flatforms-jorts-double-denim|website=Racked.com|publisher=Vox Media|accessdate=1 January 2016}}</ref> |- |[[File:Hooters Calendar Girl Melissa Poe.jpg|100px]] | '''[[Dolphin shorts]]''' | A specific style of gym shorts (see below), very short, originally made from nylon with contrasting binding, side slits, and rounded corners, popular in the 1980s.<ref name=mansour>{{cite book |last1=Mansour |first1=David |title=From Abba to Zoom a pop culture encyclopedia of the late 20th century |date=2005 |publisher=Andrews McMeel Pub. |location=Kansas City, MO |isbn=9780740793073 |page=126 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7GN0E_diWbAC&pg=PA126}}</ref><ref name=negley/> The name is a corruption of [[Dolfin Swimwear|Dolfin]], the American company that first produced the original running shorts in the 1980s.<ref name=negley>{{cite news |last1=Negley |first1=Erin|title=Which 'Wet Hot American Summer' outfit is made in Pennsylvania Dutch country? |url=http://lancasteronline.com/features/trending/which-wet-hot-american-summer-outfit-is-made-in-pennsylvania/article_59aded40-5660-11e5-8f5f-8fd7bc951be0.html |accessdate=1 January 2016 |work=Lancaster Online |agency=[[LNP Media Group]] |date=8 September 2015}}</ref> One high-profile wearer of 'dolphin shorts' is the fitness guru [[Richard Simmons]], who in 2012, boasted of owning 400 pairs of vintage Dolfins.<ref>{{cite news |last1=McGinnis |first1=Sara |title=Richard Simmons' new life as Dickie Jukebox|url=http://www.sheknows.com/entertainment/articles/958729/richard-simmons-new-nickname-dickie-jukebox|accessdate=2 January 2016|work=SheKnows.com|date=27 April 2012}}</ref> In 2012, it was reported that orange Dolfin shorts are specified as part of the uniform for waitresses at [[Hooters]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Finkel|first1=David|title=At Hooters, Men are Men and the Women are Girls. Anbody got a problem with that?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/at-hooters-men-are-men-and-the-women-are-girls-anbody-got-a-problem-with-that/2012/10/02/9ad5a954-0cb0-11e2-bb5e-492c0d30bff6_story.html|accessdate=2 January 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=2 October 2012}}</ref> |- |[[File:US Navy 041110-N-0413R-001 Machinist Mate 3rd Class Lorne Semrau of Harrisburg, Pa., keeps in shape while underway by working out one of the many treadmills aboard USS Nimitz (CVN 68).jpg|100px]] | '''[[Gym shorts]]''' | A generic term for shorts specifically designed for [[sportswear (activewear)|sportswear]]. |- | [[File:Bebe Hot Pants 01 2008.jpg|100px]] | '''[[Hotpants]]''' ''or'' '''Hot pants''' | The term "hot pants" appeared around 1970 as a description for extremely short shorts, made in luxury fabrics such as velvet and silk, emphasising their role as fashion garments rather than practical wear.<ref name=cumming>{{cite book |last1=Cumming |first1=Valerie |last2=Cunnington |first2=C.W. |last3=Cunnington |first3=P.E.|title=The dictionary of fashion history |date=2010 |publisher=Berg |location=Oxford |isbn=9781847887382 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=glBf_El4Qd4C&q=hotpants#v=snippet&q=hotpants&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Steele |first1=Valerie |authorlink1=Valerie Steele|title=Fifty years of fashion : new look to now |date=2000 |publisher=Yale University Press |location=New Haven |isbn=9780300087383 |page=87 |edition=English |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xqEt6Dpb4TYC&pg=PA87}}</ref> In 1976, [[Eleanor Lambert]] noted that the term "hot pants" had been coined by ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'' to describe fashions innovated by the French ready-to-wear company [[Dorothée Bis]].<ref name=lambert>{{cite book|last1=Lambert|first1=Eleanor|authorlink1=Eleanor Lambert|title=World of fashion : people, places, resources|date=1976|publisher=R.R. Bowker Co.|location=New York|isbn=9780835206273|pages=53, 132|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q-jbAAAAMAAJ&q=%22hot+pants%22}}</ref> Lambert also credits [[Mariuccia Mandelli]] of the Italian fashion label [[Krizia]] with designing the first "hot pants" in 1970.<ref name=lambert/> Hotpants are also increasingly credited to [[Mary Quant]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Werlin |first1=Katy |editor1-last=Blanco F. |editor1-first=José |editor2-last=Hunt-Hurst |editor2-first=Patricia Kay |editor3-last=Lee |editor3-first=Heather Vaughan |display-editors = 3 |editor4-last=Doering |editor4-first=Mary |title=Clothing and Fashion: American Fashion from Head to Toe |date=2015 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=9781610693103 |page=160 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hDkVCwAAQBAJ&pg=RA3-PA160 |chapter=Hot Pants}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Hamer |first1=Louise |last2=Blum |first2=Stella |editor1-last=Clark |editor1-first=Rowena|title=Fabulous Fashion 1907-67: Exhibition from the Costume Institute, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York|date=1 January 1981|publisher=International Cultural Corporation of Australia}}</ref>
Whilst the term "hotpants" is used generically to describe short shorts (see below) made in any material, similar garments had been worn since the 1930s.<ref name=50yrs>{{cite book |last1=Russell |first1=I. Willis |last2=Porter |first2=Mary Gray|editor1-last=Algeo |editor1-first=John|editor2-last=Algeo |editor2-first=Adele S.|title=Fifty Years Among the New Words: A Dictionary of Neologisms 1941-1991 |date=1993 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=9780521449717 |pages=167–8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3x-umCIwEYQC&pg=PA167 |chapter=Among The New Words}}</ref> Very short men's shorts may also be occasionally called hotpants.<ref name=50yrs/> |- |[[File:Knopflatz Lederhose ca. 1940 cropped.jpg|100px]] | '''[[Lederhosen]]''' | Leather shorts, often worn with matching [[suspenders]] connected by a chest band, traditionally associated with [[Bavaria]], Germany; and countries formerly part of [[County of Tyrol|the Tyrol region]] and [[Austria-Hungary]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Geczy |first1=Adam|editor1-last=Lynch|editor1-first=Annette|editor2-last=D. Strauss|editor2-first=Mitchell |title=Ethnic Dress in the United States: A Cultural Encyclopedia |date=2014 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=9780759121508 |pages=185–6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tiEvBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA185 |chapter=Lederhosen}}</ref> |- | [[File:Turnhosen wiki.jpg|100px]] | '''[[Running shorts]]''' | [[File:Trail runner at the Ullswater Trail Race 2011.jpg|thumb|100px|Trail running shorts]] A form of gym shorts designed specifically for running. They are typically lightweight, very short and split at the side (to enable freedom of leg movement), with an inbuilt [[briefs]] lining.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Spilling |first1=Michael |last2=Fishpool |first2=Sean|title=Long distance running for beginners |date=2012 |publisher=Rosen Pub. |location=New York |isbn=1448848148 |page=16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h_HWFpjacQQC&pg=PA16#}}</ref> [[Nylon]] is a popular fabric for running shorts as it is lightweight, quick-drying and hard-wearing.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hayhurst|first1=Chris|title=Ultra marathon running|date=2002|publisher=Rosen Pub. Group |location=New York, NY |isbn=9780823935574 |page=34 |edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jg2GOE5ZhxEC&pg=PA34}}</ref> Nylon running shorts first appeared in the 1970s, and despite initial resistance among men to wearing such soft, lightweight garments that felt like lingerie, nylon shorts rapidly became popular.<ref name=goodman/> An even shorter version of the running short, typically worn by [[triathlon]] participants, is called a tri-short.<ref name=goodman/> [[Dolphin shorts]] (see above) are a popular variation on running shorts.<ref name=mansour/>
[[Trail running]] shorts are typically made longer and in harder-wearing fabric that is less likely to catch and tear on protruding branches.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Barrios|first1=Dagny Scott|title=Runner's world complete guide to trail running |date=2003 |publisher=Rodale|location=Emmaus, PA. |isbn=1579547206 |page=31 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xQt9jaI7zMYC&pg=PA31}}</ref> |- |[[File:Schoolshorts1.jpg|100px]] | '''School shorts''' | Shorts designed specifically to be worn as part of a school uniform. These are traditionally made in the same manner as fully tailored trousers, with belt loops, pockets, fly fastenings, and a lining, but cut to shorts length.<ref name=hbc>{{cite web |last1=Wagner |first1=Christopher |title=School Shorts:England |url=http://histclo.com/schun/gar/pants/short/su-shortpeng.html |website=Historical Boy's Clothing |accessdate=9 January 2016}}</ref> Originally, wool [[flannel]] was used, as in long trousers, but nowadays these short trousers are more usually made from synthetic blend fabrics.<ref name=hbc/>
The traditional grey [[flannel]] shorts associated with British school uniform had become well-established by the 1920s, when they were knee-length or just above knee-length.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shrimpton|first1=Jayne|title=Tracing your ancestors through family photographs : a complete guide for family and local historians|date=2014|publisher=Pen & Sword Family History |location=Barnsley |isbn=9781781592809 |page=88 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s4FABAAAQBAJ&pg=PA88}}</ref><ref name=avril>{{cite book|last1=Lansdell|first1=Avril|title=Everyday fashions of the twentieth century|date=1999|publisher=Shire|location=Princes Risborough|isbn=0747804281|pages=57–58|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aSrWe0V_Ld4C&pg=PA57}}</ref> Up until the 1950s school shorts were also described as 'knickers' in tailoring catalogues and jargon.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Davidson |first1=Alexander |title=Blazers, badges and boaters : a pictorial history of school uniform |date=1990 |publisher=Scope Books |location=Horndean, Hants |isbn=9780906619254 |pages=166–167}}</ref> This term possibly originated as an abbreviation of [[Knickerbockers (clothing)|knickerbockers]], which began being worn by schoolboys for sports in the 1880s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Davidson |first1=Alexander |title=Blazers, badges and boaters : a pictorial history of school uniform |date=1990 |publisher=Scope Books |location=Horndean, Hants |isbn=9780906619254 |page=126}}</ref> As the term 'knickers' had become synonymous with [[panties]] in the 20th century, it was rarely used colloquially for shorts. By 2004, a study of British [[private school]]s noted that traditional grey school shorts had become denoters of private or [[Public school (United Kingdom)|public school]] uniform, as they were no longer required wear by [[state school]]s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Walford |first1=Geoffrey |title=British Private Schools: Research on Policy and Practice |date=2004 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781135783259 |page=128 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V1WQAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA128}}</ref> Similar tailored shorts form part of school uniform in a number of countries, including Australia, Singapore, South Africa and New Zealand,<ref name=hbc/> and are also part of the uniform worn by children in organisations such as the [[Cub Scout]]s. |- | [[File:Model ready to hit the runway (IMG 7651a) (5459400817).jpg|100px]] | {{anchor|Short shorts}}'''Short shorts''' | [[File:Snapshot. Eleanor and Lorraine BAnQ P48S1P12496 - cropped and straightened.jpg|thumb|100px|Posing in short shorts, 1945]] Short shorts, as their name implies, are shorter than average. Such garments had been known since the 1930s when female Hollywood stars wore them for publicity photographs,<ref name=50yrs/> and in [[New York City]], a [[by-law]] (repealed 1942) was passed banning females from wearing them.<ref name=yonkers>{{cite book|last1=Weigold|first1=Marilyn E.|title=Yonkers in the Twentieth Century |publisher=SUNY Press |location=Yonkers Historical Society |isbn=1438453949 |pages=96–99 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A_MeBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA96 |chapter=She Wears Short Shorts!}}</ref> They were principally worn for sports and active purposes, such as cycling.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Reinisch |first1=June Machover |editor1-last=Stirratt |editor1-first=Betsy |editor2-last=Johnson |editor2-first=Catherine |title=Feminine persuasion : art and essays on sexuality |date=2003 |publisher=Indiana University Press |location=Bloomington |isbn=0253215897 |page=16 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WqqMs0iXVSYC&pg=PA16|chapter=Ideal Images and Kinsey's Women}}</ref> Shorts that terminated at the upper thigh became increasingly popular as informal leisurewear and sporting attire throughout the 1940s, 1950s, and 1960s for both men and women.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Werlin |first1=Katy |editor1-last=Blanco F. |editor1-first=José |editor2-last=Hunt-Hurst |editor2-first=Patricia Kay |editor3-last=Lee |editor3-first=Heather Vaughan |display-editors = 3 |editor4-last=Doering |editor4-first=Mary |title=Clothing and Fashion: American Fashion from Head to Toe |date=2015 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=9781610693103 |page=316 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hDkVCwAAQBAJ&pg=RA3-PA316 |chapter=Women's Dress and Fashion 1946-1960}}</ref> In the early 1970s short shorts began to be made in fashion fabrics, in which form they became known as hotpants (see above), a term popularised by ''Women's Wear Daily''.<ref name=cumming/><ref name=lambert/><ref name=50yrs/> The terms hotpants and short shorts have since become interchangeable.<ref name=50yrs/> |- |[[File:ZGolfSensation.JPG|100px]] | '''[[Skort]]''' | [[File:White skort.jpg|thumb|100px]]Skort (a [[portmanteau]] of "''sk''irt" and "sh''orts''") are made with a flap of fabric in front that creates the illusion of their being a skirt from the front.<ref name=lefler2>{{cite book |last1=Lefler |first1=Anna |title=The chicktionary from A-line to Z-snap, the words every woman should know |date=2011 |publisher=Adams Media |location=Avon, Mass. |isbn=9781440531231 |page=179 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aRLhLxBl7tEC&pg=PA179}}</ref> They are often journal |last1=Staff writer |title=Snappy Skort, New for Sport |journal=LIFE |date=10 June 1957 |pages=71–76 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nz8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA71}}</ref> |- | [[File:Convertible or zip-off shorts.jpg|100px]] | '''Zip-offs''' or '''Convertible Shorts/Pants/Trousers''' | Long pants which [[zipper|zip]] off at the knee, allowing the wearer to vary the length of their trouser leg at wish. Often recommended for hiking or walking, zip-offs have been around since the 1980s.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Woodward |first1=Bob |title=Short Cuts: How to dress as cool as Gurkha in hot weather |journal=Backpacker |date=May 1985 |pages=37–39 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UuADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA37}}</ref> They are also suited to fishermen, as longer pants can easily be converted to wading-length shorts.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Beck |first1=Barry |last2=Beck |first2=Cathy |title=Fly-fishing the flats |date=1999 |publisher=Stackpole Books |location=Mechanicsburg, Pa. |isbn=0811706265 |page=91 |edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BcVvTIdwyWEC&pg=PA91}}</ref> |}

{{Other uses}} {{Slavery}} A '''thrall''' ([[Old Norse]]/[[Icelandic language|Icelandic]]: ''þræll'', [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]]: ''trell'', [[Danish language|Danish]]: ''træl'', [[Swedish language|Swedish]]: ''träl'')<ref name="vikings">{{cite book|author=Junius P Rodriguez, Ph.D.|title=The Historical Encyclopedia of World Slavery. vol 1. A - K|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ATq5_6h2AT0C&pg=PA674|year=1997|publisher=ABC-CLIO|page=674}}</ref> was a [[slave]]<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/thrall%27s?r=14 ''Thrall'' Random House Unabridged Dictionary, 2009]</ref> or [[Serfdom|serf]] in [[history of Scandinavia|Scandinavian]] lands during the [[Viking Age]]. The corresponding term in [[Old English]] was '''''þēow'''''. The status of slave (''þræll'', ''þēow '') contrasts with that of the [[Franklin (class)|freeman]] (''karl'', ''ceorl'') and the nobleman (''[[Earl|jarl]]'', ''[[earl|eorl]]''). The [[Middle Latin]] rendition of the term in [[early Germanic law]] is ''servus''. The social system of [[serfdom]] was continued in [[High Middle Ages|medieval]] [[feudalism]].
==Etymology== {{wiktionary|thrall}} [[File:En-us-thrall.ogg|thumb|Pronunciation of the term in US English]] Thrall is from the [[Old Norse]] ''[[:wikt:þræll#Old Norse|þræll]]'', meaning a person who is in bondage or serfdom. The Old Norse term was lent into late Old English, as ''þræl''. The term is from a [[Common Germanic]] ''[[:wikt:Appendix:Proto-Germanic/þragilaz|þragilaz]]'' ("runner", from a root *''þreh-'' "to run"). [[Old High German]] had a cognate, ''dregil'', meaning "servant, runner". The English derivation ''thraldom'' is of High Medieval date. The verb "to enthrall" is of Early Modern origin (metaphorical use from the 1570s, literal use from 1610).<ref>[[OED]]</ref>
The corresponding native term in [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] society was ''þeow'' (from Germanic *''[[:wikt:Appendix:Proto-Germanic/þewaz|þewa-]]'', perhaps from a [[Proto-Indo-European|PIE]] root *''tek<sup>w</sup>-'', "to run") A related Old English term is ''esne'' "labourer, hireling" (from Germanic *''asniz'', cognate with Gothic ''asneis'' "hireling", a derivation from ''[[wikt:Appendix:Proto-Germanic/asunz|*asunz]]'' "reward", from the same root as English ''[[:wikt:earn|earn]]'').
==Early Germanic law== The ''thrall'' represents the lowest of the three-tiered social order of the [[Germanic peoples]], noblemen, freemen and slaves, in Old Norse ''[[Earl|jarl]]'', ''karl'' and ''þræll'' (c.f. ''[[Rígsþula]]''), in [[Old English]] corresponding to ''[[earl|eorl]]'', ''ceorl'' and '''''þēow''''', in Old Frisian ''etheling'', ''friling'', ''lēt'', etc. The division is of importance in the [[Germanic law|Germanic law codes]], which make special provisions for slaves: Slaves are property, and may be bought and sold, but they also enjoy some amount of protection under the law.<ref>in [[Leges Alamannorum|Alemannic law]], slaves may not be sold outside of one's own province (37.1). A slave's owner is entitled to pass judgement on him, but only within the law (37.2). Slaves may not work (and may not be forced to work) on a Sunday (38)</ref> While the death of a freeman was compensated by means of a [[weregild]], usually calculated at 200 [[Solidus (coin)|solidi]] ([[shilling]]s) for a freeman, the death of a slave was treated as loss of property to his owner and compensated depending on the value of the worker.<ref>Thus, in [[Alemanni]]c law, the death of an (unfree) blacksmith was to be compensated by 40 shillings, the death of a goldsmith by 50 shillings. If either a blacksmith or a goldsmith was maimed (losing their ability to do skilled work), the compensation was 15 shillings (''Leges Alamannorum'' 41).</ref>
==Society== Thralls were the lowest class of workers in Scandinavian society. They were Northern and Eastern Europeans who were enslaved due to being prisoners of war, incurring debt, or being born into the class via their parents. Thralls in Scandinavia had no rights and their living conditions were variable depending on the master. The thrall trade as the prize of plunder was a key part of the Viking economy. While there are some estimates of as many as thirty slaves per household, most families only owned one or two slaves.<ref>{{cite book| author = P.H. Sawyer| title = Kings and Vikings: Scandinavia and Europe AD 700–1100| year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| isbn = 978-0-203-40782-0| page = 39 }}</ref>
In 1043, [[Hallvard Vebjørnsson]], the son of a local nobleman in the district of greater [[Lier, Norway|Lier]], was killed while trying to defend a thrall woman from men who accused her of theft. The Church strongly approved of his action, recognizing him as a [[martyr]] and [[Canonization|canonizing]] him as Saint Hallvard, the [[patron saint]] of [[Oslo]].<ref>[http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=658 ''St. Hallvard'' in Catholic Online. (2009)]</ref>
Despite the existence of a caste system, thralls could experience a level of social fluidity. Thralls could be freed by their masters at any time, be freed in a will, or even buy their own freedom. Once a thrall was freed, he became a "freedman"—a member of an intermediary group between slaves and freemen. He still owed allegiance to his former master and would have to vote according to his former master's wishes. It took at least two generations for freedmen to lose the allegiance to their former masters and become full freemen.<ref>{{cite book| author = P.H. Sawyer| title = Kings and Vikings: Scandinavia and Europe AD 700–1100| year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| isbn = 978-0-203-40782-0 }}</ref> If a freedman had no descendants, his former master inherited his land and property.<ref>Eyrbyggja Saga, Chapter 37.</ref>
While thralls and freedmen did not have much economic or political power in Scandinavia, they were still given a ''[[wergeld]]'', or a man's price, which is to say, there was a monetary penalty for unlawfully killing a slave.<ref>{{cite book| author = P.H. Sawyer| title = Kings and Vikings: Scandinavia and Europe AD 700–1100| year = 2002| publisher = Routledge| isbn = 978-0-203-40782-0| page = 43 }}</ref>
The era of Viking raids resulting in the capture of slaves slowly ended in the 11th century. In the following centuries, more and more thralls obtained their freedom, either by purchasing it or on the initiative of their masters, the church or the secular authority.<ref name="vikings" /> The thrall system was finally abolished in Scandinavia in the mid-14th century.<ref>Niels Skyum-Nielsen, "Nordic Slavery in an International Context," ''Medieval Scandinavia'' 11 (1978–79) 126-48</ref>
